articles.title: The State of ES5 on the Web
articles.description: Some of the earlier JavaScript build tools focused on allowing developers to write modern JavaScript code that could still run on the browsers of the time by compiling code down to ES5. Time has moved on, but have the tools or popular libraries? Philip investigates, and shares some recommendations.
articles.author: Philip Walton

articles.title: ðŸ“Š Â The Top 5000 npm Packages by Size, Downloads, and Traffic
articles.description: An interesting Google Sheets spreadsheet listing the top 5000 npm packages by package size, weekly downloads, and weekly traffic. One package is responsible for 278 terabytes of traffic per week, but the top 5000 add up to several petabytes.
articles.author: Google Sheets / danhorus

articles.title: Announcing TypeScript 5.6
articles.description: The latest TypeScript has landed with full support for iterator helpers, support for arbitrary module identifiers, --noUncheckedSideEffectImports to import modules without importing any values, and more â€” all covered in the always thorough release post.
articles.author: Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft)

articles.title: Is PHP the New JavaScript?
articles.description: Iâ€™m no real fan of PHP, but thereâ€™s been a lot of discussion on social media around increased interest in PHP by developers whoâ€™d usually steer clear of it, largely thanks to Laravel. This post tells the basic story and explains what Laravel brings to the table.
articles.author: Dave Kiss (Mux)

articles.title: The Web's Clipboard, and How It Stores Data of Different Types
articles.description: An interesting exploration of how things currently work with copy and pasting on the web, how different data types are treated, and what the Web Custom Formats proposal is putting forward.
articles.author: Alex Harri JÃ³nsson

articles.title: Building the Same App Using Various Web Frameworks
articles.description: A scientist at Amazon who usually works in Python with a minimum of JavaScript on the frontend wondered if a more modern web framework would suit him better in 2024. To try this out, he tried Next.js, SvelteKit, and the Python-flavored FastHTML.
articles.author: Eugene Yan

articles.title: Brand New Performance Features in Chrome DevTools
articles.description: A helpful look into Chromeâ€™s updated Performance Panel and all the different metrics it shows off to help you improve the performance of your site.
articles.author: Umar Hansa (DebugBear)

articles.title: React and FormData
articles.description: FormData is ironically both the â€˜newest and yet oldestâ€™ standard for accessing form data. Here are some practical ways for using it with TypeScript.
articles.author: Brad Westfall

articles.title: Biome v1.9 Released; Turns One Year Old
articles.description: Biome started life as a fork of Rome, a bold attempt to create an all-in-one â€˜frontend toolchainâ€™. As of v1.9, Biome can format and lint CSS, GraphQL, and JavaScript, does it very quickly, yet has 97% compatibility with Prettier.
articles.author: Victorien Elvinger & Biome Core Team

articles.title: Express.js 5.0 Released
articles.description: The seminal Node.js webapp library seemed to take a nap for a few years, but development was reinvigorated earlier this year. v5.0 brings a variety of modern tweaks and dependency updates, though it's still tagged next at the npm registry. (Official homepage and v5.x API docs.)
articles.author: Wesley Todd

articles.title: Jimp 1.6: Manipulate Images without Native Dependencies
articles.description: Most image libraries, such as Sharp, use native dependencies to do the heavy lifting, but Jimp can handle numerous formats directly for blurring, color tweaks, resizing, rotation, etc. Originally for Node, Jimp now works in the browser too â€“ GitHub repo.
articles.author: jimp Contributors

articles.title: Valtio 2.0: Proxy State Made Simple
articles.description: Turns objects into self-aware proxies so you can access state and subscribe to changes outside of components, add computed properties and more. Designed for React and compatible with Suspense, but can also be used with vanilla JS. â€“ GitHub repo.
articles.author: Daishi Kato

articles.title: Violentmonkey: A Way to Run Userscripts in the Browser
articles.description: There have been many extensions to run your own custom JavaScript automatically on certain Web pages over the years, but Violentmonkey seems to currently be one of the better and well maintained open source ones. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Violentmonkey Team

articles.description: Cloudflare Workers has greatly improved its npm package support. The popular serverless platform now supports a lot more Node.js APIs.

articles.title: CSS Display Contents
articles.description: Ahmad takes a a look at how best to use 'display: contents' in order to build more fluid layouts. As ever with Ahmadâ€™s work, there are plenty of code examples and use cases to help our understanding.
articles.author: Ahmad Shadeed

articles.title: The Undeniable Utility of CSS :has
articles.description: Josh has spent the past few months rebuilding his blog using modern CSS techniques, including the :has pseudo-class. Here he reflects on just how useful it is by way of some real-world use cases and some â€˜mindblowingâ€™ experiments.
articles.author: Josh W. Comeau

articles.title: CSS Triggers
articles.description: If you want to write more performant CSS, then understanding how things are rendered (layout, paint, and composite) across the three main browser engines is always going to be handy knowledge. This site brings together findings across a series of CSS properties.
articles.author: Andrico Karoulla

articles.title: A Complete Guide to Beginning with JavaScript
articles.description: A rather epic article packed with background knowledge, context, and third party resources for starting a modern JavaScript learning journey.
articles.author: Cody Lindley

articles.title: Sticky Headers and Full-Height Elements: A Tricky Combination
articles.description: Philip warns that sticky elements often donâ€™t play nicely if they have to coordinate with other elements to make up a combined height (such as 100vh). This post explores why this happens and offers up a solution.
articles.author: Philip Braunen

articles.title: Brand New Performance Features in Chrome DevTools
articles.description: A helpful look into Chromeâ€™s updated Performance Panel and all the different metrics it shows off to help you improve the performance of your site.
articles.author: Umar Hansa (DebugBear)

articles.title: Anchor Positioning Quirks
articles.description: Dives into the various potential â€˜head-scratchersâ€™ that you may come up against when working with anchor positioning, breaking them down so youâ€™ll hopefully have an easier time when you come to use them.
articles.author: Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez

articles.title: A Release Note for the Web Platform
articles.description: Details of a community-driven effort to create an index of all features across the entire web platform, which will track their availability, and share the latest information via release notes.
articles.author: Patrick Brosset

articles.title: The Web's Clipboard, and How It Stores Data of Different Types
articles.description: An interesting exploration of how things currently work with copy and pasting on the web, how different data types are treated, and what the Web Custom Formats proposal is putting forward.
articles.author: Alex Harri JÃ³nsson

articles.title: Time Travelling CSS with :target
articles.description: A fun look at how you can achieve a kind of â€˜primitive version of client-side routingâ€™ solely through the behavior of :target. A fun one.
articles.author: Lee Mayer

articles.title: svg.wtf: An SVG Playground to Learn How to Write SVG Code
articles.description: Includes some useful code-related features like tooltip info on hover, to help understand the different elements, attributes, etc.
articles.author: Amelia Wattenberger

articles.title: Redirect Checker: A URL Redirect Analysis Tool
articles.description: Includes numerous features to help analyze your redirects, like providing a detailed path analysis, bulk redirect checking, custom user-agent selection, among others.
articles.author: Sead Feng

articles.description: Similar to a desktop browserâ€™s DevTools, this lets you inspect elements, edit styles, run commands in a console, view network requests, and more.

articles.title: SVGEdit: A Powerful Browser-Based SVG Editor
articles.description: A fast, web-based, JavaScript-driven SVG drawing editor that works in any modern browser. You can try it live here or host it for yourself.
articles.author: SVG-Edit Authors

articles.description: The UK government is well known for providing its citizens with an effective, well designed Web site for performing various civic tasks. Now you can get all of their clean components in Vue 3 form.
